title: AB 1228
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature aims to support foster care agencies by providing information on admissions requirements and financial aid to California's higher education institutions. Additionally, they urge the University of California and California State University to consider using admissions-by-exemption to help homeless and foster youth transition into four-year public colleges. The California Community Colleges prioritize housing for current and former homeless and foster youth, offering them residence at no extra cost during breaks. The California Community Colleges prioritize housing for current and former homeless and foster youth, offering them residence at no extra cost during breaks and giving them priority for year-round housing. Each campus of the California Community Colleges is requested to develop a plan to ensure that current and former homeless youth and foster youth can access housing resources as needed, regardless of student housing facilities. A "homeless youth" is defined as a student under 25 years of age who has been verified as homeless within the past 24 months. A homeless services provider, director of federal TRIO or Gaining Early Awareness program, and financial aid administrator are included in the amended Education Code section. Former homeless youth retain their status for six years from admission. Each campus of the California State University with student housing facilities must prioritize current and former homeless youth and foster youth. They should offer housing at no extra cost during breaks and give priority for year-round housing. The California State University campuses prioritize current and former homeless youth and foster youth for housing, offering it at no extra cost during breaks and giving priority for year-round occupancy. Each California State University campus is required to develop a plan to provide housing resources for current and former homeless youth and foster youth, ensuring access during academic breaks. A homeless youth is defined as a student under 25 who has been verified as homeless within the past 24 months. Section 92660 of the Education Code is amended to include provisions for homeless youth, former homeless youth, and foster youth to have access to housing resources during academic breaks. The status of a former homeless youth is retained for six years from the date of admission. Each campus of the University of California with student housing facilities must prioritize current and former homeless youth and foster youth for housing, especially during academic breaks, providing it at no extra cost. The University of California prioritizes current and former homeless youth and foster youth for housing in their student housing facilities, especially during academic breaks, at no extra cost. They also give priority to these groups for residence in housing facilities that are open for occupation for the most days in the calendar year. The University of California is requested to develop a plan to ensure that current and former homeless youth and foster youth can access housing resources as needed during academic terms, including breaks, regardless of student housing availability. A homeless youth is defined as a student under 25 years old who has been verified as homeless within the past 24 months by a homeless services provider. For purposes of this section, a student who is verified as a former homeless youth shall retain that status for six years from the date of admission. This section does not apply to the University of California unless the Regents of the University of California make it applicable.
